div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: A Light Nourishment for General Use.
Allenburys' DIET
div.p: The "Allenburys" DIET is a complete milk and farinaceous Food, easy of assimilation, most agreeable to take, simply and quickly made. It is recommended in place of ordinary milk foods, gruel, etc., and whilst acceptable to all as a light nourishment, it is particularly helpful to Dyspeptics, Invalids and the Aged. In the sick-room it will be found invaluable and it is easily and quickly made, the addition of boiling water only being necessary.

The "Allenburys" DIET is readily digested by tose who are unable to take cow's milk and is particularly serviceable in convalescence. When taken as a light supper diet it will be found to promote tranquil and refreshing sleep. Although this DIET is a good for ADULTS and is entirely distinct fom the "Allenburys" Foods for Infants, yet it is also of great value as a restorative food for young children, especially during convalescence.
For Invalids, Dyspeptics & The aged.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: Helouan Races.
div.p: Our report of these races, having been delayed in transmission, cannot be to-day.

div.head: Cuarde Dinner.
div.p: , The annual dinner of the Guards Regiment, which is stationed in Cairo, will be held on the 10th prox.

div.head: Crand Hetel, Helouan.
div.p: A smal] dance with the performance of the Bracale orchestra is taking place at the Grand Hotel, Helouan, on Friday, the 27th inst.

div.head: Bourse Holidays.
div.p: The Bourses at Alexandria and Cairo will be closed on the 25th and 26th inst. for the. Christmas holidsys and on New Year, the Ist and 2nd proxo.

div.head: The Bibby Line.
div.p: Notwithstanding the fact that the Bibby Line did not jon the other first class lines in the inerease of their fares by 1° %, they have decided to allow Egyptian Government Officials a rebate of 10% off the ordinary fares.

div.head: Damanheour school.
div.p: The Damanhour School prize distribution, wires our t, was held this morning, the Mudir presiding. The Madir delivered an excellent speech and afterwards distributed monetary awards to the teachers of the kuttabs.

div.head: Railway Contract.
div.p: The Egyptian Railway Administration has accepted the tender of Messrs Ahmed Rastom, Toussoum and Co. for the supply of 200,000 pine wood sleepers at the cost of 158 and 168 milliemes per sleeper according to the system 7 transport.

div.head: Kaseala Cemetery
div.p: A Christian Cemetery bas been lately consecrated at Kassala. Father Huber, of the African Mission at Khartoum, celebrated the consecration service. Slatin Pasha, Wilkinson Bey and a largé number of the Christian population of Kassala attended the ceremonies

div.head: The Gale.
div.p: The heavy seas of the past two days have washed immense quantities of seaweed into the 'roadway on the new quay, and somewhat damaged the litebuoys recently erected by the Municipality. Quite an army of workmen are busy this morning clearing the debris.

div.head: The Meere Case.
div.p: The libel actions brought by Mr. Moore, of the P.W D., against "Al Abram," "Al Lewa," "Les Pyramides," and other local papers will come on for hearing before the Cairo Mixed Court on Monday next. Maitre Carton de Wiart will appear for Mr. Moore

div.head: Coal imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and | December 19 1,306,978 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 715,055 tons were Welsh, 162,249 Newcastle, 186,149 Yorkshire, 100,080 Scotch ponding period pf last year the imports totalled 1,222,845.

div.head: Al Hayat.
div.p: We understand that the managing board of Al Hayat intend to delete the word sanatorium from the name by which this popular Helouan hotel is generally known. Sanatorium, indeed, is quite a misnomer, especially in view of the fact that the hotel management makes it a rule not to accept consumptive persons.

div.head: Christmas at Mena.
div.p: | There will be a christmas tree at Mena House on Tuesday afternoon, the 24th inst., | at 5 pm., when the staff choir will sing a series of Christmas Carols as in previous years. Tea will be served for the occasion, and a band will play. After dinner a small dance will be held. | No invitations will be sent but all patrons of Mena are cordially invited.

div.head: Collection of Autographs.
div.p: A fine collection of autographs of which the larger part comes from famous literary men, is possessed by the General Direction of the | Berlitz School. "The branches in Alexandria, 12 rue Rosette, and 1 Sharia Kamel, thanks vo the large number of notabilities who fre quent their classes of whom the satisfaction is upanimous, will soon be in a position to possess an autograph book very interesting | for the country ot Egypt.

div.head: Big Mate in Theatres.
div.p: The enormous size of fashionable hats are most inconvenient to playgoers and the mana gement of the Alhambra Theatre at Alexandria | 'bas lately issued notices asking its patrons of the fair sex to come to the theatre hatless. Last night at the performance of I'regoli at the Alhambra only about six of the many ladies present wore hats. Mr. Conegliano begs us to thank his lady patrons for their consideration in the matter.

div.head: Our Foreign Policy. NAVAL EXPENDITURE.THE PERSIAN TROUBLES.POLICY OF NON-INTERFERENCE.
div.p: Sir B. Grey, speaking at Berwick last night, said that the German Government were embark- ing on a very large naval programme. "I have no complaint to make of that," he said in the course of his speech, "but at the same time if other nations increase their navies we shall have to.#ncrease ours. There is no need for us to be rushed into naval expenditere at the present moment as our position is perfectly secure for ore year or two, but if oar neigh- bours increase their naval expenditore largely it will not be possible for us to continue the reduction of ours."

Speaking of Persia, Sir E. Grey said that had it not been for the Anglo-Russian conven- tion it wonld have been a great temptation to Reasia or England to interfere. So long as Persia does not display any anti-foreign feeling, toreign nations should abstain from inter- ference.
A telegram from Teheran says that matters there are no worse. Russia and England will act in concert where it is necessary. A new cabinet bas been formed with Nizam es Sultaneh as Premier.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL GOLF.BRITISH CHAMPION DEFEATED.
div.p: Arnanuld, the Frenchman, has beaten our golf champion Braid at Deal.

div.head: WIRELESS TELEPHONES.
div.p: Wireless telephonic communication has been established between Berlin and Copenhagen.

div.head: MR. STEAD AND THE NAVY.ADVOCATES AN INCREASE.
div.p: Mr. Stead's pronouncement advocating an increased navy has created a storm among the peace party, who have thrown him over.

div.head: THE PALERMO EXPLOSION
div.p: The disastrous explosion at the Ajellos explosives stores at Palermo has resulted in the death of fifty persons ; one handred persons also have been injured.

div.head: LADY GORST "AT HOME"
div.p: The first dance of the season at the British Agency took place on Thursday when Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst were at home to some three hundred guests between the hours of 10 and 1 o'clock. The ball room was crowded throughout the evening, the non-dancers find- ing plenty of accomodation in the adjoining drawing rooms amid luxurious surroundings enbanced by beautiful flowers and groups of feathery foliage. Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst re ceived their guests at the entrance of the re- ception fooms, and thongh the occasion was more or léss an informal 6ne all the notabili- ties of Cairo society were present, and many beautiful toilettes and handsome uniforms were to be seen. Owing to the numbers and the congestion in the ball room it was almost an impossibility after the danciug commenced to see who was present : hence any attempt to give a list of the guests is bound to be inade- quate. But among those noticed during the evening were: Mr. Machell and Lady Valda Machell, the Count von Bernstorft and Miss Bernstorff, Mons: de Willebois and Miles. de Willebois, Sir Reginald and Lady Oakes, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Lord Edward Cecil, Sir William Willeocks, Sir Horace and Lady Pinching. Princess Irene Duleep Singh with Blanche Smitb, El) Lewa Wateon Pasha Mrs. Watson, Colonel and Miss Da Mejor and Mrs. Knight, Captain and Mrs. Herbert, Johnson Pasha and Mrs. Johnson, Coles Pasha and the Misses Coles, Captain and Mis Maclean and Miss Barnes Lawrence. and Mr. and Miss Faruell.

div.p: The Drace grave is to be opened after waa, in fact, alive until 1879, be would yet have to establish his principal contention —that which he claims would be heard in the King's Bench Division ; an application for the declara- tion of his title to the property would be assigned to the Chancery Division.

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: VISIT TO EGYPT.
(Gazette's Speoclal Service.)
London, Saturday.
It is reported that the Duke and Duchess of Connavght will pay a visit to Egypt in Pebroary next.

div.head: ISLAMIC ACTIVITY.
div.p: 130 MOSLEMS ARRESTED.
(Gazette's special service )
London, Saturday.
The "Daily Telegraph's" St. Petersburg correapondent states that 130 Mohamedans have been arrested at Erzeroum for belonging to an organisation for modifying the Turkish régime.
A petition asking the Sultan to establish a parliament was found among their papers.

div.head: AMERICA AND JAPAN.
div.p: GUARDING THE PACIFIC.
(Gazette's special service.)
London, Saturday.

The American Ambassador at Tokio, speak- ing at a banquet, said that the Pacific was a great highway forthe use of mankind and as such it must be maintained, the responsibility for which rests with Japan and America. The latter's respotsibility was the greater as having a more extensive area and greater population.

div.head: IRISH M.P. SENTENCED.
div.p: . London, Satarday.
Mr. Laurence Ginnell, M.P. for West Meath, has been sentenced to six months' imprisonment for causing a Gisturbance in Ireland and defying the Government.

div.head: DISCOVERY OF A VANDYCK:
div.p: (Gazette's special service.)
London, Saturday.
It is reported that an authentic canvas by Vandyck bas been found in the Flemish village Waesmunster. It was discovered among old stuff from a convent which was sold by auction for fourpence.

div.head: PORT SAID COAL STRIKE
div.p: Port Said, Friday.

As | wired you this morning the bonkering Arabe have come out on strike. The 8.5. "Tydens" which came out of the Cenal about 5.80 yesterday evening was the first vessel the strikers refused to coal ; she was obliged to take her bunkers in with her own crew, and up to the time of writing she is still bunkering. Coaling operations to-day have been con- ducted entirely by the ships' own crews and in all cases the work has beén slow, but the strikers have not interfered in any way. The French 8.8 "Malte" arrived here at 4 p.m. to-day and intended taking two thourand tons of coal, but upon hearing of the strike, a wire was sent to Paris asking for instructions. It is expected that she will proceed to Aden and take her bunkers there.

Several strikers collected on the quay thi morning, but they were: not allowed to aboot. Owing to the distarbances which ocourred during the last strike the Port police are making every effort to prevent them from congregating around the barbvur.

div.head: A Sensational Murder
div.p: Half a company of mounted police and a}! large draft of foot police arrived here early this morning from Cairo and are encamped at' the back of the Governor's residence ; this addition to our force should be strong enongh conducted to the Mensbieh Caracol, where he gave a statement of the deed and of the reasons which led up to it. He did not show any remorse, but on the contrary declared that he was pleas- ed at having killed Volpini.

div.head: THE MURDERER'S STORY.
div.p: The story told by Massimiliano was to the following effect. Four years he had been shot at and wounded by some in the pini, which inspired him with such hope as to the case being soon ended, that he threw up his work and returned to Alexandria. Here he found that the law's delays were intermin- menta, bat refused to hand him the certificate, which was essential to his words ensued and the lawyer ordered client to getoatof the room. The postulated and raised his stick and then Volpini drew a revolver. Massimiliano at once drew out the poignard and stabbed the lawyer many times with fatal effect. Volpini expired in the arms of one of his employés, while Massimi- liano was immediately arrested by a clerk of the office and handed over to the police.

div.head: ANOTHER VERSION.
div.p: He knowledge of the case which led up to the murder as he had only joined Volpini lately. He states that about four o'clock Felice enter- ed Volpini's office and that he was followed a few minutes alterwards by Massimiliano. After a few minutes' conversation our informant's attention was attracted by noise and he rushed to the other compartment of the room where he saw Massimiliano stab Volpini in the shoulder. He seized hold of Massimiliano and murderer attempted tostab him in the abdomen. Massimiliano, he asserts, attempted to escape, but was held until the arrival of the police by our informant and a gentleman who joined him. He asserts that Volpini drew no revolver and that the revolver, which was found on the floor, had been brought to the office that termination.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The 8.8. "Corsican Prince" with general cargo left Malta on the 20th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria oun Monday evening.
The 8.8. "Roman Prince" with passengers and general cargo left Antwerp on the 15th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 2nd January.
The 8.8. "Merchant Prince" left London on the 18th inst. and is due to arrive at Alex- to maintain order.

div.head: The Cotton Market.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
Liverpool, December 12.

Egyptian Cotton. There has been a fair demand on the Spot during the past week, with a tendency for the finer qualities to hardon. The quotations are unchanged except Good Brown which is advanced to, and Good and Fine Upperst plb

Patares have been in rather better demand, and the following are the latest quotations :Dec. 10.2 Mar. 9.60 June 9.58 Sept. 9.55 Jan. 9.69 Apr. 9.58 July 9.57 Oct. 9.53 Feb. 9.69 May 9.58 Aug. 9.56 Nov. 9.50

Amorican Futures. The market this week bas boon active both on the spot and for Paturo delivery. There have been frequent and sharp fluctuations, but today's closing values are very little changed from those of last Thursday. The anxiously awaited Ginners' roport, and that of the Agricultural Bureau have come and gone, and left as much about the same, and as much puzzled as ever.

It is hard to reconcile the Ginners' 8,338,000 and the Bureau Crop estimate of 11,678,000, but that the Crop is for short of last year's total there can no longer be any doubt ; to what extent however, will not be decided, we foar, for some time to come.

Plantors are holding their cotton for high prioos, and although later we may find that consumors will take less than last season, at present there is a large and sustained demand for the actual cotton, and apparently present values are not checking it.

The latest quotations are, delivery :December 8.904 Mar./Apl. 5.94 July/Aug. 6.93) Dec./Jan. 6.90) April/May 6.914 Aug/Sept. 5.83) Jan. (Pob. 5.92) May June 6.95, Sept./Oot. 6.71 Feb./Mar. 6,93; June/July 6.96 Oot./Nov. 6.601

Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.
